parts.fpdescription: Here you can see how a little ‘Porphyrian tree’ has been added in the inner margin even when there was hardly space
Here you can see how a later reader added large ‘NOTA’ signs as tiemarks, to clear up the puzzle of where to place the gloss.
Here you can see how a first reader went really fancyfull with inventing a new tiemark, and how a later reader drew a line between text and gloss to mark them off a bit more clearly
Paris, BnF, lat. 12949: A 9th or 10th century manuscript from a monastery
Here you can see how a little ‘Porphyrian tree’ has been added in the inner margin even when there was hardly space
Here you can see how a later reader added large ‘NOTA’ signs as tiemarks, to clear up the puzzle of where to place the gloss.
Here you can see how a first reader went really fancyfull with inventing a new tiemark, and how a later reader drew a line between text and gloss to mark them off a bit more clearly
Paris, BnF, lat. 12949 f.27 bis r
Paris, BnF, Lat. 12963, f. 8v (detail). Cassiodorus, Institutiones. Ms. from Corbie, second half of the 10th century.
Containing Augustinus’ Dialectica and John of Damascus’ Logica
Note the distinction made between mortal (and rational) man and mortal (and irrational) cows, dogs, etc.
Here, as might befit a book belonging to a theologian, Peter and Paul substitute for Plato and Socrates as examples of the species ‘man’.
Containing Porphyrius, predicamenta, periermenias, divisiones, sex principia

‘<Barbara> [erased], Celarent, Darii, Ferio, Baralipton, Celantes’ Here these names do double-duty; they remind the reader of the mnemonic verse, but they also indicate where the description of each mood can be found in the text.
Paris, BnF, lat. 17806: ca. 1250-1275, Paris University
The penwork is exquisite and detailed, the tiny lettering of the glosses is very precise and regular. Underlinings in the note show where the text is quoted.
Short summaries or marginal indices make clear what the reader can find in the text: it makes the text easier to consult.
A later reader added a Nota sign, marking a passage as noteworthy.

In the bottom margin we find a kind of diagram that often appears in these logical texts: the start of a sentence is broken up in two possible continuations, one of which is again broken up in a set of possible continuations.
Opening page of Aristotle’s Categories in Paris, BnF, Lat. 2788 (ca. 1000), f. 49r
Paris, BnF, lat. 6638 f.6 bis r
Square of opposition in BnF lat. 6638, f. 6r
Substantia, Corpus, Animatum Corpus, Animal, Homo, Socrates

In this image (Paris, BnF, Lat. 7900A, f. 132v) Dialectica is depicted as a dangerous lady: with a hook she lures students into a trap, while at the same time snakes come out of her sleeve ready to attack them.
A personification of the discipline of grammar (Lady Grammar) is teaching a schoolclass. The pupils in the front row have wax tablets to practice their letters and words.

f. 1 r. Opening of Aristotle’s Peri Hermeneias (On Interpretation) in the translation of Boethius. You may recognize this page from the teaser of this exhibition. Aristotle’s On Interpretation deals with the relationship between words, reality and logic.
Portrait of Lady Rhetoric on f.140v
Portrait of Lady Astronomy on f.151v
The art of music is illustrated on f. 153v
Written nota signs from the original annotating hand (below) and from the later one (above)
A written Nota sign in the original hand, and a drawn head as attention sign in the later hand.
A foot (?) and a hand at the edge of fol. 17v
A hand, leg or arm (?) and face on fol. 37r
BPL 144, f.43r (1) call attention to certain things
A head and peculiar animal on fol. 49v
In manuscripts, marginal notes are used to (1) call attention to certain things
Opening with the text of Martianus Capella, De nuptiis
f.2r: Opening of de Consolatio Philosophiae

In this example, the universal affirmative proposition, ‘all men are just’, is placed at the top left of the square. It’s placed alongside the other universal, but negative, proposition: ‘no men are just.’ At the bottom of the square we find the particular affirmative and negative propositions: ‘some men are just’ and ‘some men are not just’

The diagonal lines crossing the centre of the diagram (labelled ‘contradictorie’) connect propositions which are contradictory to each other. For example, if ‘all men are just’ (the universal affirmative proposition) then ‘some men are not just’ (the particular negative proposition) is a contradictory statement. If ‘all men are just’ then the statement ‘some men are not just’ cannot be true. Similarly, reading across the other diagonal, if ‘no men are just’ then ‘some men are just’ cannot be true.

The arrangement of the universal affirmative and negative propositions at the top of the square and the particular affirmative and negative propositions at the bottom is also meaningful; these are described as being ‘contrary’ to each other. That is, it is not possible for both of the universal propositions – ‘all men are just’ and ‘all men are not just’ – to be true, although they could be both false. However, while it is possible for both particular propositions – ‘some men are just’ and ‘some men are not just’ – to be true, they cannot both be false.

Finally, reading alongside the side of the square, a further relationship between the propositions, that of subalternation, is identified. If the universal affirmative proposition ‘all men are just’ placed on the top of the square is true, then the corresponding particular affirmative proposition ‘some man are just’ at the bottom of the square must also be true. Similarly, if the universal negative proposition, ‘no man is just’ is true, then the particular negative proposition, ‘some man is not just’ must also be true.

In close-up, the dirt and wear and tear on the page are even more visible. We can also see that a later hand wrote the title of the work on the top of the page: ‘Aristotelis liber i peri er[meneias] a boecio comentatus expositusque’ (see green box) (The first book of Aritotle’s Peri hermeneias, commented upon and expounded by Boethius). In the red box you can see the Greek title of Aristotle’s work, Peri Hermeneias. It is written in Greek capitals. A line over the words emphasizes the fact that it is Greek.
List of propositions in Leiden BPL 84, f. 63r

Here the scheme offers three examples of simple propositions which share one term (either subject or predicate) ‘homo animal est. animal substantia est.’ [Man is an animal; an animal is a substance’] ‘homo grammaticus est. homo musicus est.’ [Man is a grammarian; man is a musician’] ‘homo animal est. equus animal est.’ [Man is an animal. A horse is an animal]

Here the scheme represents Boethius’ account of ‘conversion by opposition’ (‘contraposition’) The second set of propositions: ‘Omnis non homo animal est. Omne animal non homo est.’ (’All non-man is an animal; all animals are not man’) shows how switching the order of the subject and predicate of the sentence generates a new proposition.

Ch: How many species are there in dialectic? A: The most important are 5: ‘isagogae’, categories, syllogistic formulas and definitions, ‘topica’, and ‘perermeniae’. Ch: What are ‘isagogae’? A: Isagoge is the (Greek) word for Latin ‘introductio’, ‘introduction’. Ch: What does ‘introduction’ mean? A: Introduction is …

Ch: What is ‘genus’? A: ‘Genus’ is what can be divided into species: it describes whatever you are investigating in an inclusive word, such as ‘animal’. For each individual species - man, horse, ox, lion etc. – ‘animal’ is the genus and is applied to them all. Ch: What is ‘species’? A: ‘Species’ is …

A medieval reader has added a content list at the end of the volume, starting with ‘libri boetius’, books of Boethius, and listing the titles. These match the existing contents of BPL 84, so we know that this collection of texts has been together since at least the time it was in this reader’s hands.
On f. 8v we find the quire signature ‘c’, suggesting that this gathering of leaves was once the third in a collection.
An example of numbers (‘ii’), from f. 32v
f. 13r: ‘Retro in libro topicorum iii’: ‘Back in book III of the Topics’
f. 14r: ‘Retro in fine libri tercium topicorum ciceronis’: ‘Back in the end of the third book of Cicero’s Topics’
Here on f. 44v, two sets of rubrics (written in red) indicate that one text has ended and that another will begin on the next page.
On f. 8r a decorated initial is used for the first word of a new text
Furthermore, a new set of quire gatherings starts on f. 17r; from this point to the end of the manuscript quires are numbered with numbers, not letters.

Text in the box: ‘According to Calcidius, entelechy is perfecta aetas, completed lifetime. According to Aristotle, it is interpreted as absolute perfection. Plato, on the other hand, says that entelechy is the anima mundi, the soul of the world.’
f.94r Opening of Priscian's De Constructione with initial of Lady Grammar
f.143r The opening of the Pseudo-Ciceronian Rhetorica ad Herennium
f.166r The opening of Boethius’ translation of Porphyry’s Isagoge
Einsieldeln, MS 315 (605), f. 139r – representation of Porphyry’s five predicables
Einsieldeln, MS 315 (605), f. 53r. This tenth-century manuscript contains one of the oldest examples of a ‘Porphyrian tree’ in a manuscript of the Isagoge.
The text has been carefully corrected, here ‘ad’ has been corrected to ‘ab’ and ‘actenus’ to ‘hactenus’.
Here small squiggles have been added in the margin alongside the text; these are rudimentary quotation marks indicating original text from the Isagoge, the subject of Boethius’ commentary.

Here interlinear glosses have been added to provide Latin equivalents of the Greek terms hyperbaton (transposition of words) and zeuma (where one word can be used in two different contexts). The glossator describes these as ‘confusus ordo’, the confusion of order, and ‘repetitio’, repetition, respectively.
These schemata (f. 11r) summarise Cicero’s discussion of the aspects of human nature (De inventione, I.XXIV.35) which are used to describe people involved in a case.
Summary in Leiden UB GRO 22, f.113v
f.3v Ramon learns Arabic from his slave
F.10r shows how Ramon is attacked by an angry mob. This single image depicts five different scenes.
The other scribe added a note on musical pitches, and a two sets of schemes regarding syllogistic propositions.
A line separates the sets of examples of syllogisms.
We know who one of these scribes was – Rather of Verona (890-974) added a copy of a letter at the base of the page.
Here you can see how each marginal note is neatly tied to its correct place in the main text with a tie mark
Paris, BnF, Lat. 7900A, f. 113r: Martianus Capella’s De nuptiis in the narrow column on the left, Remigius of Auxerre’s commentary written as a continuous tekst on the right.
Leiden, UB, VLF 48, f. 31r: example of a very full commentary added in the margin. The book is 30,7 cm high.
At the top of the scheme we find ‘Usia’ , meaning substance, a Latinised form of the Greek οὐσία. Cicero is given as the example of ‘man’

‘All that is just is good. All that is virtuous is just. Therefore, all that is virtuous is good.’ This syllogism joins two universal affirmative propositions (‘all that is just is good’ and ‘all that is virtuous is just’) and deduces the conclusion ‘all that is virtuous is good’.

In the second set of schemes lines connect terms of the propositions and conclusion in order to indicate how the argument is constructed. Visualising the argument in this way helps understand why it is valid.
The scheme is evidence of a reader trying to understand the steps made by Dialectic in reaching this conclusion; the scheme illustrates the reader’s thought process!
St Gall SB, Cod. Sang. 273 (145 x 125mm)
You can see that the material was already damaged when the scribe was copying the commentary into the margins: he/she deals with the damages parchment and the hole in it.
f. 1r: The opening of Cicero’s De inventione
Here the glossator introduces the characters in the conversation.
‘Ecce’, ‘Look’, the glossator writes – ‘an example of induction’ .

The glossator indicates who is speaking between the lines (‘Aspasia’s words’, ’Xenophon’s wife responds’ etc). These names and  characters may have been unfamiliar to the reader, so these cues helped them follow the text.
These schemata (f. 11r) summarise Cicero’s discussion of the aspects of human nature (De inventione, I.XXIV.35) which are used to describe people involved in a case.
On f. 58v, a glossator adds Augustine’s list of the eight categories of lies (De mendacio, 25).
Manuscripts were often ruled with a knife; here we can see on p. 165 that the blade has cut through the parchment while ruling the edge of the text block.

This passage of annotation gives us a clue about the kind of readers Cod. 29 (878) was expected to receive. As the first word, ‘ordo’, suggests, this gloss amounts to a reordering of the first words of Porphyry’s text (‘Cum sit necessarium...’). Glosses of this type helped medieval students make sense of Latin, and suggest that this copy of the Isagoge was prepared for an elementary readership.
Introduction to Augustine and an etymology of the word dialectica, with a reference to John Scot.
Beginning of De dialectica, with the well-known opening words: Dialectic is the art of arguing well. As you know, we use words when we argue.
Heiricus magister Remigii fecit has glossas
46r: opening of Porphyry’s Isagoge, an introduction to the Categories of Aristotle
BnF lat. 7749 f.33v. Victorinus’s commentary included a number of summary diagrams. Cicero’s text is added in red in the margins
Paris, BnF, lat. 14614, ff. 117-202 (the opening of the text is missing) date: 12th century. The manuscript belonged to the library of St. Victor, Paris
Abelard, Apologia seu fidei confessio ‘Universis’ (1141) Paris, BnF, lat. 2923, mid 13th c., f. 49 r
We should not accept this gloss - Non est haec glossa a nobis recipienda.
Paris, BnF lat. 7900, s. 10, f.133r The opening of Martianus’ chapter on dialectic, with Remigius; commentary (on the right)
BPL 144, f.43r (1) call attention to certain things

Text in the box: ‘According to Calcidius, entelechy is perfecta aetas, completed lifetime. According to Aristotle, it is interpreted as absolute perfection. Plato, on the other hand, says that entelechy is the anima mundi, the soul of the world.’
